title: 10 growth tactics that never work | Elena Verna (Amplitude, Miro, Dropbox, SurveyMonkey)
themes: Building in public and social marketing
Team building and hiring in AI startups
Women in tech and AI adoption
key_insights: Traditional growth optimization matters less than innovation and new feature development in AI companies
Product-market fit must be recaptured every 3 months in AI due to rapid technology and consumer expectation changes
Giving away AI product for free as a marketing strategy can be more effective than paid advertising
Building in public through founder and employee social media creates powerful word-of-mouth loops
Activation optimization is less important when the core product team is obsessed with first-user experience
Hire passionate, AI-native talent with high agency rather than traditional corporate experience
Focus on creating 'minimum lovable products' rather than minimum viable products
Community building and influencer marketing outperform traditional B2B marketing channels
topics_discussed: Lovable's unprecedented growth to $200M ARR in under one year
Why traditional growth playbooks don't work for AI companies
The shift from growth optimization to growth innovation
Building in public as a core growth strategy
Influencer marketing vs paid social advertising
Product-market fit as a continuous 3-month cycle
The role of vibe coders as a new job category
Women's adoption challenges in AI technology
Work-life balance in hyper-growth AI startups
Using AI tools internally for productivity
Free product distribution as marketing strategy
memorable_quotes: I feel like only 30 to 40% of what I've learned in the last 15 to 20 years of being in growth transfers here because we just need to invest in such bigger bets, and innovate, and create new growth loops here
The only way to create a word of mouth loop is just to blow their socks off
It shouldn't be minimal viable product anymore. Viability is left back in 2010s. Now it's minimal lovable product. That's the only thing that matters.
recommended_for: Anyone interested in AI company operations
summary: Elena Verna shares how traditional growth strategies must be reinvented for AI companies, using Lovable's record-breaking growth to $200M ARR as a case study. The conversation reveals why innovation trumps optimization, how building in public drives viral growth, and why product-market fit has become a continuous 3-month cycle in the AI era.
